title: Options & Derivatives Trading
description: Advanced module covering options, futures, option strategies, Greeks, and derivatives for hedging and speculation.
objectives: Understand options and futures contracts mechanics
Learn call and put options and when to use each
Master option Greeks (Delta, Gamma, Theta, Vega)
Implement basic to advanced option strategies
Use derivatives for portfolio hedging and income generation

lessons.title: Introduction to Derivatives

content.original: Derivative = Financial instrument whose value derives from underlying asset (stock, index, commodity). Types: Futures (obligation to buy/sell), Options (right but not obligation). Used for: (1) Hedging (risk protection), (2) Speculation (leverage), (3) Arbitrage (risk-free profit). Derivatives magnify gains AND losses (leverage). Lot size: Nifty = 25, Bank Nifty = 15. Expiry: Last Thursday of month. Physical vs Cash settlement. High risk - only for experienced investors with risk capital.
content.simplified: Derivative = Contract based on another asset's price. Two main types: Futures (you MUST buy/sell at future date), Options (you CAN choose to buy/sell). Why use? (1) Protection: Like insurance for your stocks, (2) Betting: Predict market direction with small money (leverage), (3) Income: Sell options to collect premium. Warning: Derivatives are powerful but dangerous - can lose more than invested. Beginners should avoid or start with very small amounts. Not for emergency or essential money.

lessons.aiSummary: Derivative = Contract deriving value from underlying. Types: Futures (obligation), Options (right). Uses: Hedging, Speculation, Arbitrage. High leverage = High risk. Monthly expiry. Advanced investors only.
keyTakeaways: Derivatives are zero-sum game (someone's profit = someone's loss)
Leverage magnifies both gains and losses exponentially
Expiry every last Thursday - time decay critical factor
95% of retail option buyers lose money (statistics)
commonMistakes: Trading derivatives without understanding (biggest mistake)
Using essential/emergency money for derivatives
Buying far OTM options hoping for lottery (usually expire worthless)
Not understanding margin requirements and MTM losses

lessons.title: Call and Put Options Explained
lessons.videoTopic: Understanding Calls, Puts, and Payoff Diagrams

content.original: Call option = Right to BUY underlying at strike price. Buy call when bullish. Put option = Right to SELL underlying at strike price. Buy put when bearish. Premium = Price paid for option. Strike price = Agreed price. ITM (In The Money), ATM (At The Money), OTM (Out of The Money). Intrinsic value = Difference between spot and strike (if favorable). Time value = Premium - Intrinsic value. Options decay to zero at expiry if OTM. Payoff diagrams show profit/loss at different spot prices. Max loss for buyer = Premium paid. Max gain unlimited (call), limited to strike (put).
content.simplified: Call option = You get right to buy stock at fixed price. Example: Stock at ‚Çπ100, you buy ‚Çπ105 call for ‚Çπ3. If stock goes to ‚Çπ115, you profit ‚Çπ7 (‚Çπ115-‚Çπ105-‚Çπ3). If stock stays below ‚Çπ105, you lose ‚Çπ3 premium. Put option = Right to sell at fixed price. Buy put if you think stock will fall. Example: Stock at ‚Çπ100, buy ‚Çπ95 put for ‚Çπ2. If stock falls to ‚Çπ85, profit ‚Çπ8 (‚Çπ95-‚Çπ85-‚Çπ2). Maximum you can lose = Premium you paid. But stock can go to zero, so put profit limited.

lessons.aiSummary: Call = Right to buy (bullish). Put = Right to sell (bearish). Premium = Option price. ITM/ATM/OTM based on spot vs strike. Intrinsic value + Time value = Premium. Buyer's max loss = Premium. Seller's risk unlimited.
keyTakeaways: Buying option = Limited risk (premium), unlimited potential gain
Selling option = Limited gain (premium), unlimited potential loss
ATM options have highest time value
Options are wasting assets - lose value every day (theta decay)
commonMistakes: Confusing call with bullish and put with bearish (can use both ways)
Buying deep OTM hoping for big gain (low probability)
Holding options till expiry (time decay accelerates)
Not understanding assignment risk when selling options

lessons.title: Understanding Option Greeks

content.original: Greeks measure option price sensitivity. Delta: Change in option price for ‚Çπ1 change in underlying. Call delta 0 to 1, Put delta 0 to -1. Delta 0.5 = ATM. Gamma: Rate of change of delta. High gamma near expiry/ATM. Theta: Time decay per day. Always negative for buyers. Accelerates near expiry. Vega: Sensitivity to volatility changes. High vega for ATM, long-dated options. Rho: Interest rate sensitivity (usually ignored). Use Greeks to predict option price changes and manage risk. Delta hedging = Balancing portfolio delta to zero.
content.simplified: Greeks help predict how option price will change. Delta: If stock moves ‚Çπ1, how much does option price move? Delta 0.5 means option moves ‚Çπ0.50 for every ‚Çπ1 stock move. Theta: How much you lose every day just from time passing (like ice melting). If theta is -10, you lose ‚Çπ10 daily even if stock doesn't move. Vega: How much option price changes when volatility changes. High volatility = Higher option prices. Gamma: How fast delta changes. Don't need to master all, but understanding theta (time decay) is crucial for option buyers.

lessons.aiSummary: Greeks = Option risk metrics. Delta (price sensitivity to underlying, 0-1 call, 0 to -1 put), Theta (time decay, negative for buyers), Vega (volatility sensitivity), Gamma (delta change rate). Essential for option trading and risk management.
keyTakeaways: Delta 0.5 (ATM) = 50% probability of expiring ITM
Theta decay accelerates in last 30 days before expiry
High IV (Implied Volatility) = Expensive options, Low IV = Cheap options
Understanding Greeks separates amateurs from professionals
commonMistakes: Ignoring theta decay (holding options too long)
Not understanding delta (position size miscalculation)
Buying options when IV is very high (overpaying)
Trading without monitoring Greeks

lessons.title: Basic Option Strategies
lessons.videoTopic: Covered Call, Protective Put, Straddle, Strangle

content.original: Basic strategies: (1) Covered Call: Own stock + Sell call. Generates income, caps upside. (2) Protective Put: Own stock + Buy put. Insurance against downside, costs premium. (3) Long Straddle: Buy ATM call + ATM put. Profit from big move either direction. High cost. (4) Long Strangle: Buy OTM call + OTM put. Cheaper than straddle, needs bigger move. (5) Bull Call Spread: Buy lower strike call + Sell higher strike call. Defined risk and reward. Use for moderate bullish view. Each strategy has specific market outlook and risk profile.
content.simplified: Popular strategies: (1) Covered Call: You own 100 shares, sell call option on them. You earn premium every month but give up huge upside if stock rockets. Good for sideways market. (2) Protective Put: You own shares, buy put as insurance. Protects against big fall but costs premium. Like car insurance. (3) Straddle: Buy both call and put at same strike. You profit if stock moves a lot in ANY direction. Use before big events (budget, election, results). High cost, needs big movement. (4) Spread: Buy one option, sell another to reduce cost. Limited profit but also limited loss.

lessons.aiSummary: Basic strategies: Covered Call (income generation), Protective Put (downside protection), Straddle (volatility play), Strangle (cheaper volatility), Spreads (defined risk/reward). Match strategy to market outlook and risk appetite.
keyTakeaways: Covered call = Income strategy for sideways/mildly bullish markets
Protective put = Insurance (costs premium but protects portfolio)
Straddle/Strangle = Volatility bets (profit from big moves)
Spreads = Beginner-friendly (defined max loss and gain)
commonMistakes: Using wrong strategy for market condition
Not calculating breakeven points before entering
Treating straddle like lottery ticket (IV crush after event)
Selling naked options without hedging (unlimited risk)

lessons.title: Advanced Strategies and Hedging

content.original: Advanced strategies: (1) Iron Condor: Sell OTM call spread + Sell OTM put spread. Profit in range-bound market. Collect premium. (2) Butterfly: Buy 1 ITM, Sell 2 ATM, Buy 1 OTM. Low cost, defined risk. Profits if stock stays near ATM. (3) Calendar Spread: Sell near-month, Buy far-month same strike. Profits from theta decay difference. (4) Ratio Spreads: Unequal number of long and short options. Portfolio hedging: Buy index puts to protect equity portfolio. Cost = Insurance premium. Dynamic hedging adjusts hedge ratio as market moves. Collar strategy: Buy put + Sell call (zero-cost protection with capped upside).
content.simplified: Advanced strategies for experienced traders: (1) Iron Condor: Bet that stock will stay in range. Collect premium from selling 4 options (2 calls, 2 puts at different strikes). If stock stays between your range, keep all premium. High probability but small profit. (2) Butterfly: Bet stock stays at exact level. Low cost strategy. (3) Portfolio Insurance: Own ‚Çπ10L stocks, worried about crash? Buy Nifty puts for ‚Çπ30,000. If market crashes 20%, put gains ‚Çπ2L+ offsetting stock losses. Like buying health insurance - costs money but protects in emergency. Best for large portfolios during uncertain times.

lessons.aiSummary: Advanced strategies: Iron Condor (range-bound premium collection), Butterfly (pinpoint accuracy bet), Calendar spread (time decay arbitrage), Ratio spreads. Portfolio hedging: Buy index puts, collar strategy. Match complexity to experience level.
keyTakeaways: Iron Condor = High probability, low profit per trade (consistency strategy)
Butterfly = Low cost but requires accurate prediction
Portfolio hedging essential for large equity holdings during volatility
Paper trade advanced strategies before using real money
commonMistakes: Jumping to advanced strategies without mastering basics
Not understanding max loss in iron condor (can be substantial)
Over-hedging portfolio (reduces returns, costs too much)
Using complex strategies with poor liquidity strikes
